From: Colin Green <cgreen@...>
Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Automatically setting the Speciation Threshold
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=127853030; y=tuI8MOTQMYEk_PxajU11C6IhPCO1oy2XKqsGWh8b42yjiq7_nDbI
X-Yahoo-Profile: alienseedpod

Hi Guys,

I was happy being a bystander on this thread as I've been thinking about 
other stuff, notably the waveform generator experiment I mentioned. But 
then my thoughts crossed over a little bit.

In a nutshell I was thinking that instead of, or as well as evaluation 
by accumulating an error value over a set of sample points, I could 
evaluate the natural frequency of each network. If the frequency is 
close to that of the target waveform then the network may still be quite 
good even though the peaks and troffs are all out of sync and therefore 
the accumulated error is really high.

Now lets say that most mutations tend towards high natural frequencies, 
I'm not sure that this the case but it's possible - new connections that 
create short cuts could do this. So my search for a low freq wave is now 
really poor because this phenomenon takes over. Even topologies with a 
low frequency that get put in their own species are soon swaped by high 
frequency genomes within their own species.

In that situation it would be nice if my speciation measure took natural 
frequency into account. That way each species focuses in on one 
particular frequency band and the search is improved. Ok maybe the 
example isn't so good. Say instead of a specific target function I have 
an indirect eval function and so the frequency dynamics I'm looking for 
are unknown. In that situation I wan't to ensure searching over a wide 
range of different frequencies.

So in the general case I would like to plug in a network or genome 
comparison scheme to drive speciation in the same way that we tend to 
plug in fitness evaluation schemes. And in fact a given experiment may 
have a number of different measures we would like to keep track of and 
cluster/speciate on. I think it makes sense for some problem domains, 
but this does potentially sounds a bit like driving evolution by 
comparing phenotypes rather than genotypes - which was another 
discussion we had some time ago.

Anyway I thought the specific example might be interesting.

Colin.
